item.title: Majority of Latin Americans Endorsed Trump’s Intervention In Venezuela, Polls Show
item.description: A majority of those surveyed said they support the intervention, suggesting a shift from ideology to pragmatism, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Celebrations in Buenos Aires after the U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro, the Venezuelan president, this month.

item.title: Trump Touts Greenland Framework as NATO Mulls U.S. Sovereignty Over Bases
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Pivot in Syria Leaves an Old Ally in the Lurch
item.description: A Kurdish force that helped defeat the Islamic State is collapsing as the Trump administration turns to back the new Syrian government.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Carlotta Gall
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Riding past a destroyed Syrian Democratic Forces vehicle on a roadside on Tuesday, near Hasakah, Syria.

item.title: Taiwan’s $40 Billion Military Spending Plan Stalled by Political Impasse
item.description: Taiwan’s domestic gridlock is revealing a deep-seated fracture over how the island should defend itself and how much it can depend on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan inspecting an F-16 fighter jet cockpit during his visit to an air base in Taitung, Taiwan, in 2025. Mr. Lai’s proposal to increase military spending has come under fire from opposition party members.

item.title: French Doctor Listened to Women’s Pain, Then Transformed How It Was Treated
item.description: Ghada Hatem-Gantzer, a French doctor, founded a one-stop shop to treat female victims of violence. Now, her revolutionary template is used across France.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Ghada Hatem-Gantzer at the House of Women medical center, which she had built in St.-Denis, France.

item.title: After Maduro’s Last Dance, a New Rhythm Goes Viral in Venezuela
item.description: For years, Nicolás Maduro and his movement used song and dance to rally support. Now, millions of Venezuelans are dancing to a different political tune.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, dancing during “Venezuelan Student Day” in November.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Gaza Kill 11, Including Three Journalists
item.description: The three journalists were operating a drone near the town of Al-Zahra.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Abdel Raouf Shaath, shown working in Rafah in 2023, was one of three journalists killed in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Starts Moving ISIS Detainees From Syria to Iraq
item.description: The U.S. military said it had transferred 150 Islamic State detainees from northeastern Syria to Iraq and could eventually move as many as 7,000, as the Syrian government assumes control of the region from Kurdish-led forces.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Eric Schmitt and Erika Solomon
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Syrian government forces guarding a position near the city of Hasakah in northeastern Syria on Wednesday.

item.title: Man Gets Life in Prison for Killing Shinzo Abe, Former Leader of Japan
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami, 45, had admitted to shooting Mr. Abe, Japan’s longest-serving prime minister; but his case divided Japan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, a former prime minister of Japan, campaigning in Nara in 2022 before he was shot.

item.title: South Korean Ex-Premier Gets 23 Years in Prison for Role in Martial Law
item.description: Han Duck-soo was convicted of playing a key role in former President Yoon Suk Yeol’s imposition of martial law, which a court said was an insurrection.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Han Duck-soo, South Korea’s former prime minister, arriving at Seoul Central District Court on Wednesday.

item.title: Carney Speech on U.S. ‘Rupture’ and Canada’s Survival Draws Standing Ovation at Davos
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney got a standing ovation in Davos for starkly describing the end of Pax Americana. He is looking for new allies to help his country survive it.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen

item.title: Prince Harry Gives Emotional Testimony About Effects of News Coverage
item.description: Harry said in court that reading articles about him published by Associated Newspapers, which he has accused of acting unlawfully, had been “traumatic.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prince Harry arriving to testify on Wednesday in London in his case against Associated Newspapers.

item.title: Photographer Discovers Train Part That Could Hold Key to Spain Train Crash
item.description: Officials said they had located a previously unreported train undercarriage near the site of a deadly train crash in Spain. Experts said the finding could help investigators.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly, Jason Horowitz, José Bautista, Christine Negroni and Roser Toll Pifarré
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The undercarriage of a train found near the crash site near Adamuz, Spain on Tuesday.

item.title: Pressured by Trump, Mexico Sends 37 Accused Criminals to U.S.
item.description: Mexico has sought to do more to combat its cartels in an effort to stave off airstrikes threatened by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexican police officers at a crime scene in Culiacán, the home territory of the Sinaloa cartel, in 2024.

item.title: Trump’s Rift With Europe Is Clear. Europe Must Decide What to Do About It.
item.description: After President Trump aired his disdain for Europe, its leaders will gather in Brussels Thursday to take stock of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Mark Rutte, the NATO secretary-general, meeting with President Trump in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Rifaat al-Assad, Paramilitary Leader and ‘Butcher of Hama,’ Dies at 88
item.description: The brother and uncle of Syrian tyrants, he commanded a unit that killed up to 40,000 civilians in a 1982 uprising against his family’s rule.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Rifaat Assad in his office in Marbella, Spain, in 2005. For more than 50 years, many of them spent in cosseted exile, he was an integral part of the family that ruled Syria with an iron fist.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Would Have Global Scope but One Man in Charge
item.description: The initiative is the latest example of the president dismantling the post-World War II international system and building a new one, with himself at the center.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel, Saudi Arabia and other nations have said they would join President Trump’s proposed “Board of Peace,” but France, Norway and Sweden have said no.

item.title: At Davos, a Clash Between Trump’s World and the Old World
item.description: For decades, leaders have gathered in Davos to discuss a shared economic and political future. On Wednesday, President Trump turned the forum into a bracing clash between his worldview and theirs.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Audience members listening to President Trump’s address at Davos on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s Talk of Greenland ‘Deal’ Framework Draws Mixed Reactions
item.description: A lot of confusion was swirling in Denmark and Greenland after President Trump’s bombshell of a post on social media.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Amelia Nierenberg and Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: People walking past a large mural in Nuuk, Greenland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s Moves on Greenland
item.description: After assailing Europe in a long speech at Davos, the president said he had won an agreement on the future of the Arctic territory.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Iran’s Protests Have Been Completely Squashed, Government Says
item.description: After a crackdown that killed thousands, Iran’s prosecutor general said on Wednesday that “the sedition is over now,” vowing to punish those responsible for the protests.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a tour for international news media shows a tax office that was burned during protests, on Wednesday in Tehran.

item.title: Did the U.S. Ever Own Greenland? Fact-Checking Trump’s Davos Speech.
item.description: The president gave misleading accounts of the U.S. role in Greenland’s history and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, among other claims.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: The New Wild Card on Travelers’ Itineraries: Uncertainty
item.description: Politics, military action and climate change have increased risk for destinations that once seemed like sure bets, forcing travelers to change how they plan.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root

item.title: Rising Global Temperatures May Affect Choices for Winter Olympic Venues
item.description: Future games will need to be held at higher altitudes, and spread over multiple venues in order to adapt to a changing climate, new research suggests.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: Gus Schumacher, a member of the U.S. cross-country skiing team, left, competing in Planica, Slovenia, in March 2023.

item.title: Stocks Rebound After Trump Backs Off European Tariffs
item.description: Stocks in the U.S. stabilized on Wednesday after an earlier slump had spilled into markets in Asia and Europe, ending a period of relative calm.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump takes questions from reporters during a news conference in the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Why Was Macron Wearing Sunglasses at Davos?
item.description: An eye condition, not a style choice, prompted President Emmanuel Macron of France to don aviators to address the World Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Heads to Davos Amid Deep Worries About U.S.-European Alliance
item.description: The gathering of the global elite is set to serve as an all-hands effort to de-escalate tensions between President Trump and America’s allies over his insistence on acquiring Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump leaving the White House on Tuesday night en route to Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum.

item.title: Another Train Crash in Spain Kills 1 and Hurts 37, Officials Say
item.description: Train service in the Catalonia region will be suspended until it is safe to resume rail traffic, the local operator said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk and Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Emergency crews responded on Tuesday after a commuter train derailed when a retaining wall collapsed onto the tracks in Gelida, near Barcelona, Spain.

item.title: Trump Escalates Tensions With European Allies With Greenland and Gaza Efforts
item.description: President Trump’s bellicose demands about Greenland and participation in his “board of peace” are deepening worries about the fate of the trans-Atlantic alliance.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked how far he was willing to go to acquire Greenland, President Trump told reporters, “You’ll find out.”

item.title: C.I.A.’s New Focus on Latin America Reflected in Raid to Seize Maduro
item.description: A senior U.S. official declined to confirm the specific operations in Venezuela, but said a covert team provided real-time support for the military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s National Guard at the entrance to the country’s largest military complex in Caracas, the capital, after President Nicolás Maduro’s capture on Jan. 3.

item.title: Trump, Venezuela and Oil
item.description: The president’s message since sending troops into Venezuela has been clear: This is about oil, not democracy.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times

item.title: What Are the Chagos Islands and the Diego Garcia Base?
item.description: The islands, which Britain has agreed to hand over to Mauritius, are home to a strategically important U.S.-British military base.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Department of Defense, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo provided by the U.S. Department of Defense showing military planes at the Diego Garcia air base in 2001. The base is used to serve U.S. Navy ships and refuel long-range bombers.

item.title: Scientists Set Up Camp on Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica
item.description: Low clouds have lifted long enough for helicopters to ferry scientists and their gear to a fast-melting glacier on the edge of Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: A Few Dozen European Troops in Greenland Set Off Trump
item.description: President Trump threatened tariffs on European nations that sent military personnel to Greenland last week. Some have already gone home, but Denmark is now sending about 100 more.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Danish soldiers disembark at the port in Nuuk, Greenland, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Seizes UNRWA’s Jerusalem Headquarters
item.description: Bulldozers leveled some structures in a compound that belonged to UNRWA, the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, escalating Israel’s crackdown on the organization.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Part of a compound in Jerusalem belonging to the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees as it was demolished on Tuesday.

item.title: A.I., Big Tech and Trump Shine Most Brightly at the Davos Spectacle
item.description: The World Economic Forum is now dominated by global technology companies whose interests shunt aside most others.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Heckles Europe Before Heading to Davos
item.description: As European leaders try to engage with the American president over Greenland and the future of Ukraine, he is mocking them as weak.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, who is scheduled to speak in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, has been heaping dismissive scorn on many of the leaders he will greet there.

item.title: U.S. Shifts Away From Kurdish-Led Forces in Fight Against ISIS
item.description: The U.S. envoy to Syria said Washington was confident the Syrian government could take over the country’s fight against the Islamic State terrorist group.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Alissa J. Rubin, Christina Goldbaum and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Kurdish security forces patrolling near Qamishli, northeastern Syria, last year.

item.title: For Syria’s Government, Kurdish Deal Is a Big Win on Shaky Ground
item.description: The government’s move to assert control over areas under Kurdish rule is a major test for President Ahmed al-Sharaa as fresh clashes erupted.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers entering the city of Raqqa on Sunday. After months of stalled negotiations with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, the government made a military push into Kurdish-held territory last week.

item.title: Australia Passes Tighter Gun Control Laws, Weeks After Bondi Massacre
item.description: Critics said the government had rushed the legislation, along with a bill targeting hate speech, in the wake of the mass shooting in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: Laura Chung
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial near Bondi Beach in Sydney, Australia, last month for victims of the shooting there, which killed 15 people at a Hanukkah celebration.

item.title: Church Leaders and Police Say Over 160 Kidnapped in Nigeria
item.description: Christian groups said gunmen abducted congregants during Sunday services at three churches.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Auwal and Dionne Searcey

item.title: Britain Approves Contentious Chinese Mega-Embassy in London
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government approved plans for a massive new Chinese Embassy near Tower Bridge, angering critics who fear it will enable spying.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Royal Mint Court, the site of the proposed new Chinese Embassy in London.

item.title: As Spain Mourns Train Crash Victims, Investigators Focus on Track
item.description: Officials on Tuesday were struggling to identify bodies from the crash near the southern city of Córdoba, which killed at least 41 people.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene near Adamuz, a town in southern Spain, on Tuesday after a deadly train crash over the weekend. Nearly two dozen autopsies have been completed, but the authorities are struggling to identify the victims.

item.title: The Northern Lights Have Inspired Humans for Thousands of Years
item.description: The aurora borealis has animated myths, art, poetry and music for thousands of years. Here are some examples.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Heritage Art/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: “Aurora Borealis,” an 1865 painting by the American landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church.

item.title: Trump Doubles Down on Greenland Threats in Flurry of Truth Social Posts
item.description: President Trump posted private messages from France’s president and repeated his desire to take over Greenland in an overnight social media storm.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump returning to the White House early on Tuesday.

item.title: Fresh Russian Strikes Cut Heat to Thousands in Ukraine’s Freezing Capital
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities say the repeated attacks on energy infrastructure are an attempt to force the country into submission.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: More than 5,600 high-rise buildings in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, were left without heat after the latest attacks from Russia, officials said on Tuesday.

item.title: With Threats to Greenland, Trump Sets America on the Road to Conquest
item.description: After a century of defending other countries against foreign aggression, the United States is now positioned as an imperial power trying to seize another nation’s land.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump has declared that the only limits on his global power are “my own morality” and “my own mind.”

item.title: A Venezuelan Political Prisoner Finally Comes Home
item.description: Ángel Godoy was thrown into jail after writing columns that angered the government of President Nicolás Maduro. Now his family is trying to make up for lost time.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Cegarra, Isayen Herrera and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ángel Godoy embracing his wife, Adriana Briceño, after arriving at home for the first time after spending a year in jail.

item.title: How Trump Flexes Power in White House Meetings With Zelensky and Others
item.description: With cameras rolling, President Trump met with more than 40 international leaders in his first year back in office.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

item.title: Islamic State Claims Deadly Attack on Chinese Restaurant in Afghanistan
item.description: A bombing that killed seven people and injured a dozen more at a noodle restaurant in a busy area of Kabul is likely to heighten China’s growing security concerns in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:description: Taliban security personnel standing guard at a blast site after an explosion in the Shahr-e Naw area of Kabul on Monday.

item.title: After Four Shark Attacks in 48 Hours, Australia Shuts Dozens of Beaches
item.description: Many of the closed beaches were in Sydney, the site of three of the attacks.
item.dc:creator: Laura Chung
item.media:description: A lifeguard attempting to locate a shark that attacked a surfer in Sydney on Monday.

item.title: The Chinese Island Where Dreams of Real Estate Glory Never Die
item.description: Intended as China’s version of Dubai’s palm-shaped artificial island, Ocean Flower Island is a $12 billion monument to debt-fueled economic excess.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Guatemalan Gang Riots
item.description: Uprisings in three prisons have killed 10 police officers, presenting another challenge for President Bernardo Arévalo in his fight against corruption and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Jody García, James Wagner and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ceremony to honor eight police officers who died in attacks by gang members the day before, on Monday in Guatemala City.

item.title: Taxing the Ultrarich
item.description: The number of billionaires has exploded, yet they often pay taxes at rates well below average.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times

item.title: How 40 People Died In a Train Crash in Andalucia, Spain
item.description: The victims of Spain’s deadliest rail crash in more than a decade included a police officer, journalists and a family returning from a musical.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, José Bautista and Samuel Granados
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency officials at the scene of the crash on Monday.
